Usage

Example of Stochastic Models

This module contains three sample stochastic model: Perturbed coin process, dual Poisson process and Nemo process. The classical models are all defined within in the script examples.py within the QMwQAE/ directory. Their corresponding parameters classes are also defined within the same file, and these classes can be imported into the experiment file to be input into the Experiment class to run the algorithm. Within the experiment.py file, there are also examples of how to initialize the relevant classes. The use of all example stochastic processes are all written, just commented out. Just run the following command within the terminal to see the algorithm in action

$ python experiment.py

You can uncomment certain parts of the code to try out different functions

Creating new stochastic models

As seen in the example classes, a new parameters class must be created. This parameters must be built on top of the Simulation_parameters class as defined in the circuit_builder.py file. This class requires the definition of the following few quantities:

  • sequence: the sequence for the algorithm to estimate its probability

  • memory_size: the number of qubits that is required for the memory register

  • starting_state: the initial causal state of the system

There are a few optional parameters that the user can define

  • sample_size: number of trials to conduct. Increasing this will help to give better estimate due to the Central Limit Theorem

  • shots: the number of shots per experiment. Increasing this also increases the precision of the estimate.

  • method: the schedule to be used for the experiment.

When the user define the new parameters class, they also have to define some variables for the algorithm to work. The user can provide the variables in three different manners:

1. The user can provide the starting vectors to populate the odd-numbered columns in the unitary matrix. This variable should be a list of numpy.ndarray vectors with the variable name self.starting_vectors. The starting vectors can be accompanied by a list of causal states also in numpy.ndarray under the variable name self.causal_states.

2. The user can provide the starting vectors, accompanied by a set of Kraus operators that define the action on the memory qubits. The Kraus operators should be provided in a list of numpy.ndarray under the variable name self.kraus.

3. The user can provide the Kraus operators with the Markov order of the process, under the variable self.markov_order, and the past, under the variable self.past.

The user should also provide two different variables for saving of data

  • self.graph_dir: the directory to save the graphs generated

  • self.data_dir: the directory to save the data generated

Exporting to Qiskit

This package allows the user to embed the Grover iterator and the algorithm operator into the EstimationProblem class provided by Qiskit. This allows the user to export the circuit created to be used with other algorithms within the Qiskit package. The export function is within the experiment.py file, called Experiment.export_estimation_problem. The user can initialize the Experiment class with the defined parameters object. Calling the function export_estimation_problem with the variable export set as True will export the EstimationProblem object with the pickle module, saving the object in the estimationProblemPickled.pkl file.

my_expt = experiment.Experiment(my_params) # my_params is the defined parameters object
my_expt.export_estimation_problem(export = True) # file saved if export set to True

To import the pickled file, use

problem = pickle.load(<path-to-file>)

alternatively, the Experiment.export_estimation_problem can also output the EstimationProblem object directly

problem = my_expt.export_estimation_problem()

An example of how to use the EstimationProblem object is given in the file qiskit_qe.py under the QmwQAE/ directory.
